text: Thank you for let me know this :)

super nice.
too late haha, i was working on a version for reproduce this [url=https://www.instagram.com/p/CFAKY9vhueo/]one[/url]
but not finished at this moment, it is indeed long time to tune
Awesome! Good to see this shader again :)
Superb. In my top 3 favourites of the competition.

A couple of hours to place everything and sculpt the shadows.

The light source is spherical - it's the circular sun light from my previous works but adjusted to be at a point in space rather than pointing in a global direction. The solid angle of the light is the same regardless of distance so it's technically physically incorrect.

The rules of 4k Executable Graphics are
- render a single static image
- on any PC platform (Win/macOS/Linux)
- with a maximum executable size of 4096 bytes
- and a maximum render time of 30 seconds
(see the bottom of [url=https://2020.revision-party.net/competitions/graphics-competitions]this page[/url])

"manually placed the primitives and nudged them around" (and this by the numbers +recompile, I guess): wow ! how long did it  take ?

BTW I realize it means that there are no curve in the face silhouette, just polygonal smoothed by penombra. Efficient illusion !

I don't get the shape of the light source: is it a cylinder ? 

"Revision 2020 / 4k": I don't find the technical rules on their website (and I'm not familiar with demo competitions): here there were no limit of duration or perf of base code, "just" the limit of size ? (size of binary, I guess: mean all people have to be on Windows, & have the same brand of GPU ? )

While I was working on it, I embedded an image of a face outline and drew it as a semitransparent overlay.
From there I manually placed the primitives and nudged them around to match the outline.
I'm curious: how did you proceed to find the proper design ? try and error, or did you got some algorithm ? or easing design process ? ( or do you know tutos / design making of ) about it ?

More inspiring models by Kumi Yamashita: [url]https://www.google.com/search?q=Kumi+Yamashita&tbm=isch[/url]
( And more shadow sculpting: [url]http://zarfoubo.blogspot.com/2009/06/theatre-dombres.html[/url]
I love stuff like this. Really elegant.
